III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Grievance handling
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12210
Section • (1) An agency shall have a written grievance handling
Description procedure as mandated by section 8a of the foster care
and adoption services act, 1994 PA 203, MCL 722.958a,
and known as the 'foster parent's bill of rights law.'
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Foster parent filed a grievance with foster care agency and there
is a concern that the grievance policy was not followed.
Investigation
Relative Caregiver was interviewed on 1/14/2025 via
telephone. She reported on 9/10/24, Adoption Worker (AW)
came into her home to complete an adoption assessment and was
rude towards her. She reported AW accused her of having drugs
in her home and "putting words in her mouth." Relative Caregiver
reported AW left her home and she contacted the agency, spoke
with Chief Administrator (CA) and complained about AW’s
behavior, but to her knowledge, nothing occurred regarding her
complaint. Relative Caregiver reported she shared with CA that
she never wants AW back into her home. She reported she has
been working with the agency for five years and she has never
been spoken to or treated in the manner by any other staff
member from the agency who has come into her home. Relative
Caregiver reported she is aware that nothing occurred with AW
because AW continues to come into her home. Relative Caregiver
admitted she never filed or wrote a written grievance with the
agency. She reported she made complaints to CA about the
rudeness of AW and did not want AW to come into her home.
Relative Caregiver reported a Family Team meeting (FTM)
occurred via zoom on 11/25/24, with Foster Child A’s (FCA)
Paternal Grandmother who lives in the State of Ohio for visitation
and AW started the meeting without FCA's attorney present.
Relative Caregiver reported the Paternal Grandmother for FCA's
case had discussed availability for FCA's visits to Ohio and
Relative Caregiver said she was demanded by AW to send her
reservation. Relative Caregiver said again she felt disrespected
and talked to rudely. Relative Caregiver reported the meeting was
2

confidential and Paternal Grandmother from Ohio had people in
the background listening to the conversation between her and
Paternal Grandmother. Relative Caregiver said she felt this was
out of order and going against policy of confidentiality.
Relative Caregiver reported AW came to her home on 11/24/24
and talked with FCA without her permission behind closed doors.
Relative Caregiver reported she felt bullied from this worker from
the day AW started working with her case. She said upon talking
with FCA, AW accused her of whooping FCA and that she has
never hit FCA and does not believe in physical violence.
Relative Caregiver reported she feels that AW favors the Paternal
Grandmother involved in adopting FCA and this might be the
reason AW is rude towards her.
Interview with Adoption Worker (AW) via telephone 1/27/25.
she reported she was assigned FCA's adoption case on 7/21/24
when the last worker resigned from the agency. AW denied
accusing Relative Caregiver of having drugs in her home. She
explained Relative Caregiver was posting on Facebook of how
she dropped her daughter off at a drug house and observed her
granddaughter coming out of the same drug house. AW reported
she discussed with Relative Caregiver how this posting was
inappropriate and for clarification purposes she was concerned
about FCA being in the vehicle with Relative Caregiver dropping
her child off at a known drug house and in that type of
environment. AW said she was concerned for FCA’s safety and
discussed with Relative Caregiver how this type of environment
was not conducive for FCA to be around.
AW explained there was a zoom meeting to hold a Family Team
Meeting on 11/24/24 to discuss FCA’s visitation schedule with the
competing party (Paternal Grandmother) in Ohio. The meeting
involved Relative Caregiver (Maternal Grandmother), FCA’s
Paternal Grandmother, Paternal Grandmother’s son, who is the
substitute caregiver for the Paternal Grandmother and FCA’s
attorneys from Michigan and Ohio, and herself. AW reported the
discussion only centered around FCA’s day and overnight visits to
Ohio. AW said FCA’s Michigan attorney was a few minutes late
but was there to hear what was discussed concerning FCA’s
visitation to Ohio.
AW reported she interviewed FCA in private when she went to the
home to gather information for Relative Caregiver’s adoption
assessment. She said FCA told her Relative Caregiver whoops
3

him with a belt. AW said she and FCA joined the Relative
Caregiver in the living room and FCA repeated this information in
front of the Relative Caregiver. AW said FCA grabbed the belt and
started hitting Relative Caregiver on the buttock with the belt. AW
reported she discussed discipline with Relative Caregiver such as
redirecting him, removing his favorite toy but absolutely no
physical discipline. AW reported Relative Caregiver denied that
she has ever hit FCA or engaged in any type of physical discipline
with him. AW said when she left the home, she reported the
allegations to centralize intake. AW reported a safety plan was put
in place by her agency foster care department.
AW reported she remains neutral to both parties involved with
FCA’s adoption. She said she reports only the facts and remains
professional at all times. AW reported Relative Caregiver was
completing the adoption process timely but had to be put on hold
due to Paternal Grandmother which brought about some
frustrations of having to start the process over. AW reported she
has no animosity towards the Relative Caregiver. AW denied ever
bulling or being rude towards Relative Caregiver. AW reported to
her knowledge, no grievance was filed against her but the CA and
PM talked with her regarding being rude towards Relative
Caregiver and Relative Caregiver did not want AW to come back
into her home. No additional information was added.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed via telephone on
1/27/25. She reported she was assigned to FCA’s case 11/14/24
and that she is relatively new on the case. She reported she has
made five face- to- face home visits to the home of Relative
Caregiver and FCA to check on his well-being and discuss any
issues the Relative Caregiver might be having. She reported she
has had no issues with communication with Relative Caregiver
and that Relative Caregiver welcomes her into her home. She
added she also reviews agency policies and reviews the safety
plan that was written for Relative Caregiver as a result of an
allegation she received in November 2024 regarding disciplining
FCA. She said the plan was written on 12/4/24 and is working fine
with no issues. She added no additional information.
Interview with CA (CA), Program Manager (PM) and Quality
Director via Microsoft Teams on 1/15/2024. CA reported she
contacted Relative Caregiver prior to this complaint allegation on
11/25/24, to discuss any issues she was having with AW and/or
agency. She reported Relative Caregiver told her she was not
happy, and she did not want AW to come back into her home. CA
4

reported she wanted to clarify and ask Relative Caregiver if she
would like to proceed with a written grievance on the agency/AW
and Relative Caregiver replied, no. CA reported she and the PM
had a conversation with AW regarding being rude and/or bulling
Relative Caregiver. CA reported that AW reported absolutely not
and that she follows protocol and is professional with the Relative
Caregiver at all times.
CA reported she contacted and explained to Michigan Children’s
Institute (MCI) Superintendent that Relative Caregiver wanted to
change the current AW on FCA’s case and did not want the
worker to return back to her home. CA reported MCI
Superintendent felt the current AW change was not necessary and
that it would just further delay FCA’s adoption. CA said she
contacted Relative Caregiver after speaking with MCI
Superintendent and explained to Relative Caregiver that as a
function of AW’s role, she has to have face-to-face visits with FCA
in their residence but that CA or the PM would join AW to ensure
professionalism and appropriate conversations occurs at all times.
CA reported Relative Caregiver asked if she could have the police
present. CA said she informed Relative Caregiver that at all
costs, she tries to avoid having children see the police unless it is
warranted. CA said she informed Relative Caregiver she and the
PM would ensure there is no escalation that would require police
involvement. She said she ended the conversation by
emphasizing that at any time Relative Caregiver wanted to file a
written grievance on the agency, she may do so.
Program Manager (PM) reported to her knowledge, at no time
has Relative Caregiver come forward and requested a grievance
towards the agency or AW. She said she is aware that Relative
Caregiver does not want AW in her home because she is the PM
of AW and issues are discussed in meetings. She did not have
any additional information and supports the CA decision of going
to Relative Caregivers home when AW goes to the home for face-
to-face visits.
Quality Director did not have any additional information to add.
She reported that AW does not have any discipline actions in her
personnel file.
Documents Reviewed:
• FCA’s case record. FCA is a five-year-old placed with
Relative Caregiver, maternal grandmother on 4/22/19.
• Relative Caregiver case record was reviewed. It is noted
that Relative Caregiver is the maternal grandmother of
5

FCA. The competing party is the Paternal Grandmother of
FCA.
• Relative Caregiver Safety Plan for FCA dated and signed
by Relative Caregiver on 12/4/24 was reviewed.
• MCI Superintendent response to the removal of AW from
Relative Caregiver case. Email dated 12/5/24, from the
MCI Superintendent states, “I don’t think a worker change
is necessary, it would just further delay adoption.”
• The agency grievance policy states: “Concerns,
disagreements, or complaints from foster parents, birth
parents, prospective adoptive parents and clients will be
addressed promptly and respectfully. At all stages, staff will
strive to negotiate an acceptable solution to the stated
problem. Services to the client and their foster family will
not be affected in any way by filing a complaint. Foster
Parent, Birth Parent, Prospective Adoptive Parent, and
Client concerns. Foster/birth/adoptive parents or clients
should meet with the Program Manager to discuss
issues/concerns as soon as possible. If the results of this
meeting are not satisfactory, the Program Manager will
advise the parent of the procedure for a formal complaint.”
Analysis The agency is found in compliance per interviews with staff and
documentation. Relative Caregiver admitted she did not file a
written grievance on AW but complained to the CA how rude AW
was towards her and that she did not want the AW back into her
home. MCI Superintendent stated the change of AW is not
necessary as this process will delay FCA’s adoption. CA and PM
have agreed to accompanying AW when goes in the Relative
Caregiver’s home to ensure protocol and professionalism as well
as any type of escalations while the adoption process for FCA is
occurring.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
6

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
